message:
Participants receive the following upon joining the machine learning program:
- 18 hours of live, interactive sessions
- 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions
- A final project with direct feedback
- 100 coding assignments and practice questions
- The entire source code of a working production system
- Access to a private community for collaboration
- Direct access to the instructor
- Lifetime access to every past and future cohort
- Program certificate upon completion
Yes, live sessions of the program are recorded.

The cost to join the program is $500 and it includes lifetime access to all past, present, and future cohorts, 18 hours of live interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project with direct feedback, 100 coding assignments, access to the source code of a working production system, a private community for collaboration, direct access to the instructor, a program certificate upon completion.
Answer: The cost associated with joining the program is $500, which is a one-time payment for lifetime access with no monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs.
The next cohort for the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' program is scheduled for February 3 - 20, 2025.
Some strategies mentioned for active learning in the course include uncertainty and diversity sampling strategies.

From the machine learning program, you will gain practical skills such as designing and writing code to build an end-to-end machine learning system from scratch, learning best practices to tackle significant challenges faced by machine learning engineers in real-world scenarios, and using techniques like active learning, distributed training, adversarial validation, human-in-the-loop deployments, model compression, and test-time augmentation.
Santiago is the contact person mentioned in the context.

In the context of the program, 'lifetime access' means that once you pay to join the program, you will have immediate access to every past, present, and future cohort. You can participate in as many iterations as you'd like without any additional fees or costs.

The program's live sessions for building machine learning systems include discussions on the first principles behind building machine learning systems, step-by-step coding instructions, and opportunities to interact with the instructor and other students in real time.

To enroll in the program, one must pay a one-time fee of $500. There are no monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs associated with joining the program. Once the payment is made, participants receive lifetime access to every past and future cohort, as well as all program resources and updates.

The resources and benefits provided upon enrollment in the machine learning program include:
1. 18 hours of live, interactive sessions
2. 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions
3. A final project with direct feedback
4. 100 coding assignments and practice questions
5. The entire source code of a working production system
6. Access to a private community for collaboration
7. Direct access to the instructor
8. Lifetime access to every past and future cohort
9. Program certificate upon completion

Unique or exclusive materials provided include:
- The entire source code of a working production system
- Direct feedback on the final project
- Lifetime access to every past and future cohort

You'll design and write the code to build an end-to-end machine learning system starting from scratch. You'll learn best practices to tackle the most significant challenges machine learning engineers face to build, evaluate, run, monitor, and maintain machine learning systems in real-world scenarios.

The upcoming Cohort 17 of the program will start on February 3, 2025, and end on February 20, 2025. Live sessions will take place every Monday and Thursday at 10:00 AM EST, with office hours on Wednesdays. On Tuesdays and Fridays, participants have individual work time.

The copyright for the materials made available is registered under Tideily LLC. The specific rights reserved are not mentioned in the context provided. The contact email mentioned is svpino@gmail.com.

The main subjects discussed in Session 1 of the program include:
1. The difference between production machine learning and traditional machine learning.
2. Strategies for solving the right problem with the right solution.
3. Critical questions to ask before starting any project.
4. Techniques for problem framing, inversion, and the haystack principle for building successful applications.
5. The first rule of machine learning engineering and how to start building.
6. Data collection strategies.
7. Techniques for determining how much data is needed for a project.
You can access recordings of the live sessions from the Machine Learning School program if you decide to attend classes asynchronously later using the recording.
The strategies for active learning highlighted in the course include uncertainty and diversity sampling strategies.

The exact start date for the upcoming cohort of the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' program is February 3, 2025. The program runs for 3 weeks with live sessions every Monday and Thursday at 10:00 AM EST, and additional sessions on Wednesdays.

In the context of the program, 'lifetime access' implies that once you pay to join the program, you will have access to every past, present, and future cohort. This means that you can benefit from updates and improvements in each new iteration of the program without having to pay again.

Someone interested in coding should set aside 2 to 4 hours weekly to complete the code walkthroughs and work on the assignments in order to effectively participate in the course and implement the concepts discussed in class.

Participants in the program mentioned in the context will gain practical skills in building machine learning systems, problem framing, critical thinking, data collection strategies, coding instructions, and project completion. These skills are designed to be accessible to a wide range of participants, including those with disabilities, to ensure inclusivity and accessibility in learning machine learning concepts and applications.
The strategies covered in the course for active learning in the context of addressing selection bias and ensuring data diversity include uncertainty and diversity sampling strategies.

Yes, in the context of the program, 'lifetime access' means that participants will have ongoing access to all course materials and updates, even if they are unable to complete the program due to unforeseen circumstances.
I don't know.

The cost to join the program is a one-time payment, and the fee includes lifetime access to 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project with direct feedback, 100 coding assignments, the entire source code of a working production system, access to a private community, direct access to the instructor, lifetime access to every past and future cohort, and a program certificate upon completion.

Upon joining the machine learning program, you receive resources and materials that address handling selection bias and data labeling. These include information on human annotations, natural labels, and weak supervision for data labeling, as well as strategies for dealing with selection bias.
The next cohort for the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' program is scheduled to begin on February 3, 2025.

The specific topics covered in the first session of the machine learning program include:

1. What makes production machine learning different from what you've learned.
2. The strategy to solve the right problem using the right solution.
3. Critical questions to ask before starting any project.
4. Problem framing, inversion, and the haystack principle for building successful applications.
5. The first rule of machine learning engineering and how to start building.
6. Data collection strategies. A technique to determine how to collect data effectively.

For someone who prefers to watch recorded sessions at their own pace, they can access the recording of the first session and go through these topics step by step to understand and learn at their convenience.
The one-time payment structure for joining the program is $500, and there are no additional costs associated with accessing advanced modules or resources.

"Lifetime access" in this context means that once you pay to join Santiago's program at the Machine Learning School, you will have immediate access to every past, present, and future cohort. This includes 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, step-by-step coding instructions, a final project, coding assignments, the source code of a working production system, access to a private community, direct access to Santiago, and more. You can participate in as many iterations of the program as you'd like without any additional fees.
The payment structure for enrolling in the program is a one-time fee with no monthly or annual fees.

Yes, the live sessions are recorded so you can watch them later if you are unable to attend them in real-time.

Upon joining the machine learning program, you would receive lifetime access to 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project with feedback, 100 coding assignments, the entire source code of a working system, access to a private community, direct access to your instructor, a program certificate upon completion, and the ability to join every past and future cohort.
Cohort 17 starts on February 3 and ends on February 20, 2025. Live sessions will take place every Monday and Thursday at 10:00 AM EST, with additional sessions on Wednesdays.

You would learn techniques like active learning, distributed training, adversarial validation, human-in-the-loop deployments, model compression, test-time augmentation, and testing in the machine learning program that offers practical, real-world skills.
The next cohort for the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' program is scheduled for February 3 - 20, 2025.

The topics covered in Session 2 of the course on the Machine Learning School Website are:
- The role of data cleaning and feature engineering to build better models
- Turning data into numbers using vectorization techniques
- Producing homogeneous features using normalization and standardization
- Handling and interpreting missing values using imputation techniques
- The approach to choosing the best model to solve any problem
- Random baselines and the zero-rule algorithm
- How to use overfitting to build models that don't suck
- Hyperparameter tuning and experiment tracking
- Measuring the quality of your holdout set
- An introduction to distributed training using data parallelism and model parallelism

These topics focus on various aspects of building machine learning models, including feature engineering, hyperparameter tuning, model selection, and training techniques.
The cost structure for joining the program at the Machine Learning School is a one-time payment of $500, which gives you lifetime access to all past and future cohorts.

The program offers a live, interactive, and practical learning approach for machine learning. Participants receive 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project with direct feedback, 100 coding assignments and practice questions, access to the complete source code of a working production system, a private community for collaboration, direct access to the instructor, lifetime access to past and future cohorts, and a program certificate upon completion.

Some key benefits offered by the program include lifetime access to all past and future cohorts, 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, 100 coding assignments, access to the complete source code of a production system, learning how to start freelancing on Upwork, feedback and support from the community, direct feedback from the instructor, and a program certificate upon completion.

The topics covered in the first session include:
- What makes production machine learning different from what you've learned
- The strategy to solve the right problem using the right solution
- Critical questions to ask before starting any project
- Problem framing, inversion, and the haystack principle for building successful applications
- The first rule of machine learning engineering and how to start building
- Data collection strategies
- A technique to determine how to start building with complete confidence

The focus of the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' course is to help individuals build production-ready machine learning systems from the ground up. The next cohort is scheduled to start on February 3 - 20, 2025.

Contact person: Santiago
Company mentioned: Tideily LLC

The practical skills you will gain from the Machine Learning School program include designing and writing code to build an end-to-end machine learning system from scratch, learning best practices for tackling challenges faced by machine learning engineers in real-world scenarios, and using techniques like active learning, distributed training, adversarial validation, and more. 

The unique aspects of the program include lifetime access to all past, present, and future cohorts, direct feedback from the instructor, a private community for collaboration, a final project with direct feedback, 100 coding assignments, and access to the complete source code of a working production system.

The strategies discussed for active learning in the course include uncertainty and diversity sampling strategies. The course covers techniques for handling missing values such as imputation techniques.

The cost structure for joining the machine learning program is a one-time payment with no monthly or annual fees. The program is designed for technical professionals such as software engineers, data scientists, data analysts, machine learning engineers, technical managers, and anyone who wants to use machine learning to solve real-world problems.

The schedule for the program's weekly activities is as follows:
- Monday: Live session for 2 hours
- Tuesday: Individual work
- Wednesday: Optional office hours
- Thursday: Live session for 2 hours
- Friday: Individual work

The cost to join the program is a one-time payment of $500 with lifetime access. There are no monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs. Participants can access every past, present, and future cohort with this one-time payment.

In the context of the machine learning program, 'lifetime access' means that once you pay to join the program, you get immediate access to every past, present, and future cohort. You can benefit from updates and improvements in each new iteration of the program without any additional cost. The instructor of the program is Santiago, a machine learning engineer with over two decades of experience building and scaling enterprise software and machine learning systems.

If you are attending the live sessions, you should set aside a minimum of 4 hours every week during the three weeks of the program. This commitment will be enough for engineer leaders or anyone not interested in the coding portion of the program. Those interested in implementing the concepts discussed in class should set aside 2 to 4 hours weekly to complete the code walkthroughs and work on the assignments. Yes, live sessions are recorded.
